A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Least common multiple to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of the least common multiple (LCM) provided explicitly mentions an element $v \in R$ and other elements $x_1, \ldots, x_n \in R$, where $R$ is assumed to be a set with certain algebraic properties. The properties of divisibility ($x_i \mid v$ and $v \mid a$) used in the definition of LCM are meaningful only within a structure where multiplication is defined and behaves according to certain rules. These rules are part of the definition of a ring, specifically where $R$ is a monoid with respect to multiplication. Without the concept of a ring, the operations and relations described in the definition of LCM, such as divisibility and the existence of common multiples, would not have a well-defined mathematical framework. Therefore, the concept of a ring is necessary to provide the algebraic structure within which the definition of LCM makes sense.
